title: Improve Zombie Models to Look Like Call of Duty-Style Zombies

requirements.text: Redesign the StandardZombie 3D mesh in EnemyMesh.tsx to resemble a Call of Duty-style zombie: add a more humanoid body with visible torso, arms, and legs as separate geometric segments; give the head a skull-like shape with sunken eye sockets (dark hollow eye geometry); add torn/ragged clothing geometry (overlapping flat planes or box segments with dark/blood-stained colors); use a desaturated, pale greenish-grey skin tone for body parts; add protruding jaw/lower-face detail; keep toon-shading but shift colors to necrotic (pale green-grey skin, dark red blood accents, torn dark-brown clothing).

quotes: verbessere die modellierung der zombies , das sie mehr wie richtige zombie in call of duty aussehen

acceptanceCriteria: StandardZombie has a distinct head, torso, two arms, and two legs as separate mesh segments
Head geometry includes sunken/hollow eye socket detail (dark recessed geometry)
Body parts use a pale greenish-grey toon-shaded color matching a CoD undead aesthetic
Torn clothing is represented by overlapping dark-brown/black geometric planes on the torso and arms
Blood accents (dark red) are present on clothing/body segments
Walking bob animation still functions correctly on the new mesh
Hit flash and death fade effects still apply correctly to the new mesh

requirements.text: Redesign the BossZombie 3D mesh in EnemyMesh.tsx to look like a heavily mutated CoD boss zombie: larger bulkier torso with uneven shoulder masses, oversized arms, a deformed enlarged skull, exposed bone/rib geometry on the chest, glowing red/orange sunken eyes (emissive small sphere geometry), and heavily torn dark clothing. Use a darker necrotic skin tone than the standard zombie to visually distinguish it as an elite threat.

quotes: verbessere die modellierung der zombies , das sie mehr wie richtige zombie in call of duty aussehen

acceptanceCriteria: BossZombie is visually larger and more imposing than StandardZombie
BossZombie has an oversized deformed skull with emissive glowing red eye geometry
Chest area includes exposed rib/bone geometry (light-grey protruding planes)
Shoulders are asymmetric and bulkier than the standard zombie
Arms are elongated/oversized relative to the body
BossZombie uses a darker, more decayed skin tone than StandardZombie
Existing hit flash, wave bob, and death fade animations still function on the new mesh

requirements.text: Add a subtle idle sway/lurch animation to both zombie types in EnemyMesh.tsx: the torso should lean forward slightly and arms should hang low with a side-to-side shoulder sway, mimicking the iconic CoD zombie lurch movement. This should complement the existing walking bob animation.

acceptanceCriteria: Both zombie types have a forward torso lean of approximately 15–25 degrees
Arms hang lower and swing side-to-side during the walk animation
The lurch animation is driven by the existing frame-based animation system (useFrame)
Animation does not cause performance regression (no new per-frame allocations)

constraints: All changes must be confined to frontend/src/components/Game/EnemyMesh.tsx
Do not break existing hit flash, death fade, or wave bob animation logic
Do not modify any file under frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.ts, frontend/src/hooks/useActor.ts, frontend/src/main.tsx, or frontend/src/components/ui
nonGoals: Adding new enemy types or changing enemy AI/pathfinding logic
Modifying enemy health, damage, or spawn logic
Changing weapon models or any other 3D asset outside of EnemyMesh.tsx
Importing external 3D model files (GLB/OBJ) — geometry must remain procedural using Three.js primitives
